Uses for thought about coercion || Coercion, freedom, and voluntariness
3.4 Political/legal theory and coercion

As the historical section of this entry suggests, the relationship
between states, law, and coercion has been a subject of vast
discussion throughout Western philosophical history. Many of the most
pressing issues belong to a discussion of states and law rather than
to a discussion of
 coercion.[26]
 However, some theorists have attempted to draw some fairly
revisionist lessons about politics and law from their theoretical
discussions of coercion. This work is worth consideration here, since
their conclusions may impact how we understand the nature of coercion,
and its place in law and politics.
3.4.1 The coerciveness of law

As noted above, there are a number of accounts of coercion that insist
that coercion is a violation of right, or otherwise normatively
defective, of which Alan Wertheimer’s Coercion is the
most prominent. But if coercion is necessarily immoral action, then it
is hard to explain how an act of coercion could count as
 justified.[27]
 Among other implications, this view is in apparent contradiction with
the traditional approach to coercion which treats states as
paradigmatically, even necessarily users of coercion. As William
Edmundson has pointed out (and as Nozick 1969, had noticed), if the
state is justified in punishing wrongdoers, then when it threatens to
do so, it does not threaten to make them worse off than they ought to
be (Edmundson 1995 and 1998, chs. 4–6). Hence on an approach to
coercion that insists it is immoral activity, the state’s use of
police powers to enforce the law is not coercive.

Could this be right? It hinges, first, on whether one accepts a
moralized analysis of coercion; if one can give a non-moralized
account of coercion, then the grounds for the claim are much more
tenuous. It would also seem to depend on whether the moral evaluation
of the coercer’s action is an “all things
considered” judgment, or merely a pro tanto one. While
the government’s use of coercion may be all-things-considered
morally benign, the threat of jailing someone may count as pro
tanto wrong in a way that, say, paying a reward is not. If so,
then even on a moralized account we may suppose that government
coercion requires special justification before it can be accepted.
Wertheimer, Haksar, Lamond, and Oberdiek, for instance, seem to find
no problem accepting that there is “justified coercion”
— that is, acts which are coercive on a moralized theory of
coercion (baseline or otherwise), yet which are ultimately justified
by other considerations (Oberdiek 1976; Haksar 1976; Wertheimer 1987;
and Lamond 2000 and 2001). Edmundson, however, argues that such a view
is unmotivated and not required by a moralized theory, properly
understood. If he is right, then the uses of what are normally thought
of as coercive techniques do not call for special scrutiny if they are
constrained to the support of just, procedurally sound law.

Edmundson’s criticism of the canonical view of the state as
coercive reveals a deeper root to some disagreements over coercion. In
effect, Edmundson provides a reason to question how special or
important coercion really is. Coercion may make some actions
necessary, but human beings in any natural world will be constrained
by necessities of many sorts: the physical limits of our bodies in our
environments, and our needs for things such as nourishment, shelter,
protection, and even perhaps community, recognition, and love. To be
coerced adds to or alters in some ways what it is necessary for one to
do. But being subject to a coercive set of laws might also provide one
greater opportunities or freedom from necessity, as arguably the
criminal law does, at least if well-drafted and
 enforced.[28]
 If just laws provide us protection from wrong-doers while leaving us
at liberty to take any morally justifiable act (assuming here that the
criminal law prohibits only unjust acts), then the law’s
threatened use of force against lawbreakers may not merit any special
scrutiny. We might instead regard it as a shifting, regularization,
and rationalization of the necessities to which human beings are
anyways subject. Edmundson and those he disputes with can all agree
that coercion used for illicit ends is a matter of moral significance
and a cause for special scrutiny and opposition. What Edmundson shows
is that moralized approaches to coercion make it hard to see why the
technique itself and the agents who can use it are especially worthy
of our attention.

One might thus object to moralized accounts on the grounds that we
have reason to track and scrutinize uses of this technique whether
performed well or badly, justly or unjustly. This is because when an
agent has the power to coerce willy nilly, as the state does, it is up
to such an agent to decide what purposes it will use its powers for.
Natural necessities are typically predictable, stable requirements on
our actions, persisting without regard to us as individuals. By
contrast, powerful agents are not necessarily predictable, stable, or
indifferent to us as individuals. Rather, they can target and direct
their powers to suit their purposes. Of course we hope that they are
constrained by justice, but even mostly just governments are likely to
enact bad laws or have rogue elements within them. Hence there is
value in having a concept to pick out the sort of technique used in
law enforcement, forced migrations, mafia protection rackets,
back-alley robbery, and the training of some recalcitrant children,
since one and the same state might use the same tools and techniques
to engage any or all of these sorts of activities, with only the whim
of the leader or parliament to decide which it shall be.

A slightly less radical, though still revisionist claim about the
coerciveness of law, holds that the coerciveness of law resides in its
claim to a right to use (or authorize the use of) enforcement power.
Drawing a distinction between the state and its apparatuses on the one
hand, and the law on the other, Grant Lamond argues that the
coerciveness of law should not be thought to depend on the fact that
the state has such things as police departments and prisons as its
enforcement mechanisms. Rather, he argues that the coerciveness of law
resides in its claim to a “right to authorize the
enforcement of [its subjects duties, responsibilities,
etc.]… It is not that legal duties are sanction-based, nor that
every law must ultimately be linked to coercive measures, but that law
claims the right to back up its directives with force”
(Lamond 2001, 55). He later clarifies this view to point out that the
law claims indeterminate authority to enforce its
dictates.

Lamond’s aim in making this distinction is to clarify what he
sees to be several possible confusions. First, he argues that the
law’s coerciveness need not depend directly on the state’s
own enforcement apparatus; the state might use vigilantes, private
contractors, or other private means for this
 function.[29]
 Moreover, he aims to limit law’s responsibility for coercive
acts to just those that it in fact authorizes: extra-legal uses of
coercion by the state should not be chalked up to law’s
coerciveness. He also argues that some of the coercive enforcements
that law uses are not themselves uses of force; instead, one might
confiscate bank accounts or take away rights in non-tangible property
(such as intellectual property protections) as means to pressure
subjects to comply with the law. Lamond holds that if such
interventions exert sufficient pressure on the will of those
considering a particular option, such that they change course, then
they may be counted as coercive, even if they do not involve the
threat or imposition of sanctions conditioned on the activities of the
people governed (Lamond 2000, 56–57). Lastly, like Edmundson, he
aims to downplay the supposed role that coercion plays in our
appreciation of the law, holding that many of law’s functions do
not depend specifically on its function of authorizing (or not
authorizing) enforcements on the subjects. “It is easy to
exaggerate the role of coercion in maintaining the efficacy of the
legal system, and to overestimate its capacity to sustain
efficacy” (Lamond 2001, 57).

Lamond’s claim about law’s coerciveness stems from a
number of considerations, but undoubtedly one is his understanding of
the nature of coercion itself, which was discussed in Section 2.5
above. Whether or not his account of coercion is tenable, what Lamond
says about why law is coercive generates independent difficulties.
Even if the law claims to authorize the enforcement of its
subjects’ duties, it is not clear why the mere claiming
of such authorization would suffice to make the claiming coercive. The
laws of a state may well provide for and instruct agencies or
mechanisms to serve as its enforcers (e.g., police, vigilantes, or
robots); but if these enforcers quit, or are bought/killed/shut off,
the coerciveness of the law will quickly evaporate. If, for instance,
the army decides to side with the protestors rather than the
government, the law loses its force in a hurry, no matter how
legitimate. Moreover, were a private association or other institution
to “lay claim” to use such indeterminately bounded
enforcement powers, what would determine whether in fact they ended up
being coercive is whether in fact they managed to engage in
enforcement activities through agencies or mechanisms similar to those
that states regularly use, or so Lucas points out. (Lucas 1966,
61–2) A church, for instance, might even leverage its threats
with claims about the final disposition of one’s mortal soul.
But this sort of claim to reward and punish does not give the church
the ability to coerce, at least as this concept is usually understood
in political contexts.

Some have argued directly that law does not require coercive backing
in order to count as law (e.g., Raz 1975), holding that what is
instead important is that law is made by the appropriate authority
(see also Oberdiek 1976). Going further than this, Robert Hughes
argues that there can be laws a state is entitled to make but not
entitled to enforce. “Whether a government is entitled to
enforce any given legal restriction coercively depends on concrete
empirical facts, not only on abstract truisms about human nature, and
on moral features of the restriction in question” (Hughes 2013,
184). Such empirical factors on Hughes’ account include whether
compliance can be obtained through non-coercive means, and what the
costs of using coercion to secure compliance would be. Responding to
Joseph Raz, Edmundson, and Lamonde, inter alia, Ekow Yankah
defends the traditional view connecting law and coercion, contending
that “Legal norms must be ultimately enforceable by coercion to
be included in the core concept of the law” (Yankah 2008, 1198).
After developing his own non-moralized conception of coercion, Yankah
argues that law requires not only authority but the ability to compel
obedience. There are, after all, many different possible normative
systems, for example religious ones, that claim to have moral
authority to command obedience, but law is distinctive among them
because it has the possibility to compel compliance with the edicts of
justified authorities. Countering Raz’s view that coercion might
be merely instrumentally needed, Yankah asserts, “the inability
of any structure to even theoretically compel [a lawbreaker] to obey
would cast serious doubt on the system’s claim to be the
law” (Yankah, 2008, 1236; for others on this side of the dispute
see Himma 2016 and Woodbury-Smith 2020).
3.4.2 The coerciveness of states

Moving from the question of how law relates to coercion to the broader
question of how states and politics more generally relate to coercion,
there are a number of ways that political theory addresses the role of
coercion as a tool of statecraft, and offers arguments about how
coercion conditions the scope and legitimacy of political action. Max
Weber famously defined the state in terms of its legitimate
monopolization of physical coercive force within a territory:


A political organisation will be called a “ruling
organisation” to the extent that its existence and the validity
of its orders can be continually guaranteed within a given
geographical area by the application and threat of physical coercion
by an administrative staff. An institutionally organised political
enterprise (Anstaltsbetrieb) will be called a state if, and
to the extent that, its administrative staff can lay claim to a
monopoly of legitimate physical force in the execution of its orders
(Weber 2019 [1921], §17, 135–136; See also Weber 1946
[1921]).


Liberals, broadly construed, have been impressed with the power of the
state and its potential both for misuse as well as partisan domination
over and sectarian interference with dissenters, and thus have
identified its employment of coercion as generating a distinctive set
of political concerns. For instance, G. E. M. Anscombe argues that if
states are to be distinguished from mafias, it is only because they
may, if well ordered, earn authority over their subjects, which she
understands as “a right to be obeyed” (Anscombe 1981,
132). Judith Shklar, in her “Liberalism of Fear,” draws
attention to the distinctiveness and historical rarity of the modern
liberal state as one in which the power of the government is
constrained by foreswearing the use of cruelty and fear as tools of
statecraft (Shklar 1989). Others, such as Charles Larmore and Gerald
Gaus, take coercion to be a distinctively problematic interpersonal
imposition. Hence, because states are understood to be the
preeminently coercive agents, the justification of the state depends
in significant part on whether there is sufficient justification for
its use of coercion to secure compliance with its decisions (see
Larmore 1996, ch. 6; Gaus 2003).

Echoing Weber, in A Theory of Justice, Rawls distinguishes
the “legal system” of a state by “its comprehensive
scope and its regulative powers with respect to other associations.
The constitutional agencies that it defines generally have the
exclusive legal right to at least the more extreme forms of coercion.
The kinds of duress that private associations can employ are strictly
limited” (Rawls 1999 [1971], 207), and “By enforcing a
public system of penalties government removes the grounds for thinking
that others are not complying with the rules. For this reason alone, a
coercive sovereign is presumably always necessary, even though in a
well-ordered society sanctions are not severe and may never need to be
imposed” (Rawls 1999 [1971], 211). In his later Justice as
Fairness: A Restatement, he regards coercion as an intrinsic
feature of state political activity: “Political power is always
coercive power applied by the state and its apparatus of
enforcement” (Rawls 2001, 40). He goes so far as to suggest that
if people in a society could attain their goods harmoniously, without
resorting to private coercion or relying on public coercion to resolve
conflicts, it would be “a society in a certain sense beyond
justice. It has eliminated the occasions when the appeal to the
principles of right and justice is necessary” (Rawls 1999
[1971], 249). Rawls goes on to argue for the importance of justice as
the primary regulative virtue of the basic structure and institutions
that determine the distribution of benefits and burdens to members of
society (Rawls 1999 [1971], 4).

Although Rawls does not offer a detailed explication or defense of his
understanding of coercion, due to the outsized influence of his
political theory, his thinking about the place of coercion in politics
has set the terms for several debates in this area. One issue that
bears the distinctive mark of his thinking is whether and why the
principal object of justice is the basic structure of a society, and
how that structure should be delimited. Expressed in terms somewhat
less specific to Rawls, we may query whether the state is distinctly a
user of coercion, and what difference this might make to the question
of its activities should be regulated. Another area for inquiry
considers whether there are special limits to a state’s use of
coercion, and/or whether it needs to meet some special condition for
its justification (for this way of structuring the concerns here, see
Kolodny 2017 and 2018). Some, following Rawls, argue that some form of
public justification that speaks to all reasonable members of society
is required to justify the state’s use of coercion; others
reject this requirement, while supporting other grounds of
justification instead. And still others hold that the state’s
use of coercion does not require distinctive justification or need to
be limited to only a specific range of purposes. A third line of
inquiry asks whether there are implications from the state’s use
of coercive power for determining the scope of the obligations of
justice. Some, again following Rawls, hold that because members of a
single polity are mutually subject to the power of coercion that they
materially facilitate, they have distinctive obligations of
distributive justice to one another that do not apply to those not
similarly part of the same polity. Others object to this argument on a
number of grounds.
3.4.3 Are states distinctively coercive?

The first set of inquiries here concerns whether the state’s
coercive activities are distinctively coercive, compared to other
social institutions and practices. One reason Rawls offers for
applying his principles of justice to the “basic
structure” of society (which includes such things as the
political constitution, the major social institutions and practices
that structure human relationships, such as the family) is
“because its effects are so profound and present from the
start” (Rawls 1999 [1971], 7). While it appears clear that the
state, via its coercive determination of law and institutions like the
economic system, constitutes much of the “basic
structure,” it is hardly the only source of profound
constraining effects on the lives of its subjects. This point is
pressed by G. A. Cohen, who argues regarding Rawls’s principles
of justice that their application should not be limited to just those
parts of the “basic structure” of society that are the
outgrowth of the state’s coercive institutions. Cohen then
argues that a social institution such as the structure of the family
is something that is largely determined by conventional social
practices rather than by the coercively-backed laws of the state. Yet
few aspects of a society’s structure will have more profound
effects on the life prospects and possibilities for action than the
way family structures are organized. Since these are not defined by
the state’s coercive apparatus (or so Cohen suggests),
there’s no reason why the principles of justice should be
limited to regulating just the parts of the social structure that owes
its existence to the state’s coercive impetus (Cohen 1997).
Whether or not one holds that the social structures one is born into,
such as a particular set of family arrangements, count as coercive,
their structure is largely outside the bounds of the state coercive
enforcement, even though they constrain choice and possibility in a
way little different from state coercive decisions.

While accepting that the family, in some of its aspects, should be
counted within the “basic structure” and thus is
accountable to principles of justice, Blain Neufeld argues that there
is good reason to restrict concern with social justice to just those
social institutions that are “organized and maintained through
the collective exercise of coercive power” (Neufeld 2009, p.
37). The state’s use of power is distinctive in two ways: it is
an activity of the whole collective body, so requires justification to
all of those who are part of that body. And the whole of that society
is subject to it; it is normally very difficult or impossible for
individuals to exempt themselves from a state’s coercive
jurisdiction. The use of coercion here is not arbitrary, since the
functioning of these public institutions depends on their being able
to provide assurance to society’s members that everyone will be
subject to the same terms and obligations, and that their
contributions and cooperation will be reciprocated by others (Neufeld
2009, 43). While other social institutions in a well-ordered society,
such as religions or cultural institutions, may have profound effects
of many members of a society, it remains possible for individual to
reject their authority and jurisdiction. Hence they are
“voluntary” associations in a way that the state is not
(Neufeld 2009, 42).

Neufeld, following Susan Moller Okin (See Okin 1994 and 2005), argues
that in Rawls’ later writings he treats the structure of the
family in particular as more like one of these voluntary associations,
rather than properly part of the basic structure, and so does not fall
within the scope of principles of justice. However, Neufeld points out
that in contemporary liberal states there are a wide range of coercive
laws and state-organized facilities that regulate family structure and
the possibilities for association there, thus making it much more an
effect of state coercive power than are religions, cultural
associations, and many other forms of private association. Thus the
state is more directly implicated in the structure of the family than
Rawls or Cohen seem to register. (See here also Brake 2012 for the
ways in which state power constitutes legal marriage.)
3.4.4 Does state coercion need special justification?

A different aspect of Rawls’ approach holds that coercion is
itself a distinctive political activity, and distinctively in need of
justification to the members of a polity. Rawls here accepts what
seems to be a broadly held view that coercion is an especially
problematic way for one party or entity to treat another party, which,
if right, makes the issue of how to justify its use by the state
pressing. One might ground this view in the concern Kant expresses in
the “formula of humanity”: “So act that you use
humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other,
always at the same time as an end, never merely as a means”
(Kant 1997 [1787], AK 4:429). To coerce someone appears to be a
paradigmatic way of overriding their own decision about what they
should do, and directing their will to serve one’s own purposes,
rather than purposes of their own, thus treating them solely as a
means rather than as an end themselves. As Charles Larmore puts the
point, “the distinctive feature of persons is that they are
beings capable of thinking and acting on the basis of reasons. If we
try to bring about conformity to a political principle simply by
threat, we will be treating people solely as means, as objects of
coercion. We will not also be treating them as ends, engaging directly
their distinctive capacity as persons” (Larmore 1996, 137; see
also Pallikkathayil 2016, 174).

For this reason, many liberals hold that state coercion must be
subjected to some further constraint or justification that that
explains how at least some exercises of coercion are consistent with
treating those who are coerced as ends in themselves, and not merely
means. Perhaps the dominant approach is one Gerald Gaus and
Christopher J. Eberle have called “justificatory
liberalism” (which Eberle associates also with the work of
liberals such as Rawls, Larmore, and Robert Audi) which makes the
justification of coercion its central mission. “The claim that
respect requires public justification provides a basis for the central
component of the justificatory liberal’s ethic of citizenship:
the norm of respect imposes an obligation on each citizen to
discipline herself in such a way that she resolutely refrains from
supporting any coercive law for which she cannot provide the requisite
public justification” (Eberle 2002, 12, emphasis omitted; see
also Gaus 2010).

There is now a very large literature, arising out of
Rawls-interpretive scholarship, attempting and criticizing this
justificatory task, which extends well beyond the issues raised by
state coercion; this entry is not suited to address it in any detail.
(See instead the Stanford Encyclopedia entries on
“Public Reason,” “Public Justification,”
“Liberalism” and “Political Legitimacy.”) But
relevant here are some rebuttal arguments that reject or qualify the
claim that the state’s use of coercion is especially in need of
such justification. Several authors have argued that state uses of
coercion are not necessarily problematic in a way that encumbers them
with a special justificatory burden, or at least not a burden that is
owed to those subjected to state coercion.

In response to the presumption against state coercion that motivates
the liberal justificatory projects, Andrew Lister raises a number of
objections to such a presumption (Lister 2010). While Lister
acknowledges that paternalistic uses of coercion—aimed at the
well-being of those coerced—would be hard to justify against
those whose choices are overridden for their own good, he argues that
other exercises of state coercion may be more defensible than the
“reasonable rejectability” test would seem to allow. He
argues that although there may be disagreements based in publicly
acceptable reasons about whether a particular use of coercion may be
warranted or desirable, a polity’s citizens might reasonably
agree to accept, say, authorizing a government to enact a set of
coercive policies (which may include some that some individuals would
reject), rather than requiring that each individual policy be tested
for reasonable rejectability, which might result in all of them being
rejected by someone or another. That is, it may be reasonably
unrejectable to adopt as a compromise a process that enacts some
coercive state policies that are, as a package, preferred by everyone
in comparison to a situation in which nearly all uses of coercion are
disabled by one or another party’s specific reasonable objection
to it. This solution is one Joseph Chan, developing the idea from
Thomas Nagel, calls the “principle of higher-order
unanimity”: if people can and should unanimously agree that a
state must use coercion out of practical necessity, then this
principle can be adopted as reasonably unrejectable, and then used to
justify specific coercive policies even if some citizens might
subsequently have reasonable objections to those particular policies
(Chan 2000, Nagel 1995).

Lister defends this proposal against objections from Gaus’s
liberal neutrality (Gaus 2003) that hold state coercion to be
distinctively problematic, and so demand that every coercive state
action be individually vetted for reasonable rejectability. For one
thing, Lister points out that policies that invoke state coercion may
differ in their acceptability depending on what other policies are in
place. He offers as an illustration that it may be reasonable to favor
stronger property rights against the state in a society with broadly
egalitarian distribution of wealth, whereas it may be more justifiable
to allow eminent domain to override property owners’ rights
where there is broad inequality of ownership and little redistributive
taxation (Lister 2010, 158). Moreover, state coercion is often used to
combat private coercion, or other harms of a similarly disruptive
character; it is not obvious that we should prefer a state that allows
private coercion to one that uses coercion itself against private
coercion. Furthermore, Lister argues, it is also unclear how to
measure the extent of coercion as an output of a state’s policy
choices, which is another obstacle to a presumption against state
coercion for the sake of avoiding coercion more generally.

Colin Bird also argues against the view that being coerced by the
state is a distinctive ground necessitating that coercers justify
their actions to the coercees. He argues that other ways in which a
majority might exclude equal protection to minorities not involving
coercion would be similarly problematic, suggesting that the problem
with state coercion is not specifically due to the effect of coercion
on those coerced. For instance, if a state organized a voluntary cash
lottery to fund some sectarian mission, making it independent of the
use of taxation, he argues that this would raise similar problems of
reasonable rejectability by those whose interests are ignored by this
program. Moreover, he notes that objections to coercion need not be
due to its effect on those coerced: people might even reasonably
object to a coercive policies even if they are immune to that
coercion, as a male might reasonably object to laws forbidding
abortion even if he is not liable to suffer its enforcement (Bird
2014, 198). Bird instead thinks that because the state acts on behalf
of all of its citizens, the requirement of public justification
attaches to its decision because they speak on behalf of everyone, and
so should be justifiable to all as co-authors of those decisions. But
this then severs the need for public justification from the coercive
quality of some of those decisions.

In a similar vein, Niko Kolodny and Christopher Morris contest the
significance of the state’s use of coercion to the question of
whether state power can be legitimate by liberalism’s lights.
Kolodny registers the concerns of civic republicans that it’s
the state’s superior power to coerce that makes it suspect.
However, he thinks that this is based in a misdiagnosis of the concern
about the state; our worry about the state would be justified even if
the state maintained its supremacy without the use of coercion, but
rather just had widespread public assent to its decisions. Ultimately,
he holds that concern with coercion stems more from how the power of
the state seems to impugn the equality and self-sovereignty of the
members of society, and not from any special threat it poses to the
freedom of its subjects (Kolodny 2016, 2017 and 2018). Morris argues
coercion is just one tool that states use to gain compliance with
their decisions. Possessing “authority” is sufficient to
gain compliance in many decisions from at least many people, and so is
similarly in need of justification if coercion is. “One does not
understand law and, more generally, states if one does not see
coercion and force as supplementary to authority. Coercion
and force are needed when the state’s claimed authority is
unappreciated, defective, or absent. Unjust states, recognized widely
as such, will need to rely heavily on force; just states presumably
need much less force” (Morris 2012, 40 (Morris’
emphasis)). On these views, then, even if state coercion requires
justification, it isn’t a distinctively important factor in need
of special justification.

Lastly, Pallikkathayil argues that the question of how state coercion
can be justified to those coerced is wrongly posed. Developing a
Kantian approach (similar to that elaborated at greater length by
Arthur Ripstein in Ripstein 2009), Pallikkathayil argues that states
are instituted to allow people to live their lives in association with
others in a way that allows all to be mutually independent through a
system of rights that prevent unjust interference in one
another’s choices. States are required in order to specify those
rights, adjudicate claims in the breach, and enforce those judgments
so people may rely on them. With this story as background,
Pallikkathayil asks:


[W]hat I am doing when I coerce someone by subjecting her to liberal
political institutions and laws. I am actually trying to treat her as
independent by putting her in the only circumstances in which she can
be free to live her life as she sees fit consistently with everyone
else doing so as well. And this remains the case even if she
reasonably disagrees with me about the justification for the state
just given. So, on this view, what is distinctive about permissible
coercion is that it is consistent with—and in the case of the
state’s use of coercion, needed for—mutual independence,
rather than that it makes contact with the viewpoints of others in a
particular way. (Pallikkathayil 2016, 177)


Pallikkathayil then argues that this account of the function of a
state, with coercion being an essential tool for it to carry out this
function, has the advantage of restricting uses of state power to
those that facilitate or at least are compatible with this aim of
mutual independence, while providing a justification for necessary
coercion that doesn’t depend on the particular values of the
society’s members. “[A]n advantage of the Kantian’s
account of permissible coercion is that it looks to capture what is
intuitively most problematic about impermissible coercion.
Impermissible coercion involves trying to make a decision for another
that one is not entitled to make. The possibility that we might
disagree about what decision to make is orthogonal to this
concern” (Pallikkathayil 2016, 183). Hence, similar to the way
the Nagel/Lister appeal to a principle of higher-order unanimity
short-cuts the need to justify specific policies involving coercion,
Pallikkathayil’s Kantian approach justifies the coerciveness of
the state more generally, with justification of specific coercive
policies coming in at a subsidiary step where the use of coercion is
already pre-cleared, in a sense.
3.4.5 Does state coercion generate special obligations for its citizens?

The third topic arising from Rawls’ framework is the issue of
whether participation in a society governed by a coercive state
generates distinctive obligations to co-nationals, because of that
mutual susceptibility to coercion, or whether political obligations
are unaffected by this mutual susceptibility. Rawls famously limited
the applicability of the principles of justice to the boundaries of a
single polity, “a closed system isolated from other
societies” (Rawls 1999 [1971], 7; see also Rawls 1993);
relations between different polities and people across borders were
taken to be governed according to other principles. For Rawls, the
subject of justice is “the major social institutions [that]
distribute fundamental rights and duties and determine the division of
advantages from social cooperation,” (Rawls 1999 [1971], 6), the
principles of justice apply only to those united in a society that
forms the basis of such social cooperation.

While this limitation has been contested, Michael Blake and Mathias
Risse argue that it can be supported by consideration of the coercive
nature of the state. The necessity of state coercion puts citizens of
a single state in a kind of relationship to one another that differs
from their relationship to those outside their state. Blake holds that
a duty to promote economic equality as a matter of justice “is a
plausible interpretation of liberal principles only when those
principles are applied to individuals who share liability to the
coercive network of state governance” (Blake, 2002, 258). Risse
similarly accepts that states (though not just states) may bear
special obligations to those they govern due to their use of coercion
over those under their authority (Risse 2006). Risse however stresses
that it is the immediacy of the sort of legal and political coercion
states exercise over their subjects that gives those subjects special
claim to just treatment from their states and fellow citizens.

Thomas Nagel reasons likewise to a similar conclusion, and extends it
to justify the exclusion of immigrants from a state.
“Immigration policies are simply enforced against the nationals
of other states; the laws are not imposed in their name, nor are they
asked to accept and uphold those laws. Since no acceptance is demanded
of them, no justification is required that explains why they should
accept such discriminatory policies, or why their interests have been
given equal consideration. It is sufficient justification to claim
that the policies do not violate their prepolitical human
rights” (Nagel 2005, 129–30). Against this view, the use
of coercion to exclude non-citizens from a state has been argued to
violate basic rights (Huemer 2010) and principles of democratic theory
(Abizadeh 2008; for objections and replies, see Miller 2009 and 2010;
and Abizadeh 2010). As the next section will further explore, coercion
across state borders is also a contentious issue.

In response to positions like that of Blake, Risse, and Nagel, Andrea
Sangiovanni argues that people do not accrue special obligations to
their fellow citizens just because they are mutually and
non-voluntarily liable to being coerced for the sake of their common
well-being (Sangiovanni 2012). While justice may constrain what sort
or extent of coercive “will-bending” can be justified,
Sangiovanni argues that being mutually subjected to coercion does not
change what obligations one has to others similarly situated. While
not ruling out that there may be obligations arising from being
members of the same society, if such members have more demanding
obligations to share the wealth with fellow members than with
outsiders, this can’t be explained just by their common
subjection to coercion. (For a reply to Sangiovanni friendly to
Blake’s position, see MacKay 2016.)
